problem_prompt: Solve the following problem. What integer $n$ satisfies $0\le n<{101}$ and $$100n\equiv 72\pmod {101}~?$$
solution: Notice that $100\equiv-1\pmod{101}$.  Therefore if we have any multiple of 100, that number will be congruent to the negative of the number we get by deleting the final two zeros and changing the sign.  For example \[111100\equiv-1111\pmod{101}.\]In particular, $100n\equiv -n\pmod{101}$.  Therefore we want to solve \[-n\equiv72\pmod{101},\]or \[n\equiv-72\pmod{101}.\]Adding 101 does not change the residue class, so this is equivalent to \[n\equiv \boxed{29}\pmod{101}.\]
gpt_response:
To find the integer $n$ that satisfies the given congruence, we can simply brute-force it by trying out different values of $n$ until we find one that works.

\[100n \equiv 72 \pmod{101}\]

We can rewrite this congruence as:

\[100n \equiv -29 \pmod{101}\]

Now we can start trying different values of $n$ starting from $0$ up to $100$ until we find the value that satisfies the congruence. We can also simplify the computation by reducing modulo $101$ where needed.

\begin{align*}
100 \cdot 1 &\equiv -29 \pmod{101} \\
100 \cdot 2 &\equiv -2 \pmod{101} \\
100 \cdot 3 &\equiv 25 \pmod{101} \\
100 \cdot 4 &\equiv 52 \pmod{101} \\
100 \cdot 5 &\equiv 79 \pmod{101}
\end{align*}

So we find that $n=79$ satisfies the given congruence. Therefore, the integer $n$ that satisfies $0\leq n < 101$ and $100n \equiv 72 \pmod{101}$ is $n=79$.
